Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:Google Maps and other highway and street GPS services have replaced what? Choices:  A: united states B: mexico C: countryside D: atlas E: oceans<n><n>### Response:		2<n><n>### Question 5: A box of marbles is sold in four different colors. Each package contains 3 blue, 2 yellow, 2 green, and 3 red marbles. If every single package is put in a single bag, how many possible combinations are available?<n><n>### 1<n><n>### Question: 6<n><n>### The Lego Company made 6.3 billion Lego bricks in 2020. How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:The person gave a good hands on what to show how to do the work? Choices:  A: demonstration B: garage C: building D: barn E: synagogue<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n>

Choices:  A: going to jail B: going to prison C: beat him up D: get arrested E: die<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rules:<n>-The response should be in the form of a logical statement that follows the instruction-style of the original text.<n>-The response should use a question to initiate communication. (Example: To which option did you think the text was referring?)<n>-No response is complete without an indication that the respondent has received and understood the statement or question. (Example: If the question is, “Which city is older, London or Vienna?” then the response of, “I think you mean which city did you mean.” is the best response.)<n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:What is a grumpy person likely to have? Choices:  A: headache B: understand themselves C: compliments D: own house E: happiness<n><n>### Response:		Choice(A): Grumpy is a person who has a certain type of headache<n><n>### Demonication:<n>To start the task, we have to create a string for our questions. We want each one to have a choice so we must create another string that has each one as a string with 4 options, a,b,c,d,etc. Then we need to insert all options into our string so we create a new string that will hold the question and also we need to create a string name to be the variable we would call the user question.<n><n>## #Solver:<n>Our program starts it by loading the values from the input into a variable. The first value we find the second one is the questions variable name name. Then we insert a question into  the second variable. We want the second variable to accept the question and we add the choices into the question variable variable. We put a space in between each choice to make it easy to read the options, at the end of every option we want to place a point so the user won't make a question for a choice. When user enter question we will be looking for the question variable, if the question entered from user matches the variable than we put it in a list, later at the end of program when we need to print the list we can call print option and print list.<n><n>### Example:<n>```python<n>question = input("What is a grumpmat person likely to have?"<n>for choice in ["A", "B", "C", "D", "E" ]:<n><n>	question = option + " " + str(choice) <n>for choice in list() <n>print (" ", option+str(choice))<n>```<n>## Author:<n>Nasim Amini<n><n>## Contributors:<n>Ahmed Fazli<n>Daniel Arias Mori<n><n>## Contact for questions:<n>Amini_Nasim5@live.com

Below is what we can write. You can type the expression as shown in the prompt or as your own version of the expression.<n><n>Then for each part, we identify the variable. For example, in the first part, we can identify `v` as the variable. Lastly, we solve for the answer by substituting values into the expression until the variable is constant.<n><n>In Part 4b, we recognize that there is a `v` and that it is used in each case of the word "for". First, we substitute 12 for every place that `v` appears in the expression. Next, we substitute 20 for every place that `k` appears in the expression and recognize that there is a variable that represents all of the letters that come after "m", since every place that `k´ appears the variable appears too. We simplify and obtain the right answer.<n><n>### Expressions<n>We are given some information that will guide us to write the expression that represents the amount of money one receives for recycling cans.<n><n>Write the expression that represents the money someone receives for recycling 12 cans. Choices:  A: picnic B: friend's house C: table D: space shuttle E: fairgrounds<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n><n>### Instructions: Complete the math story and then solve for the number in the question.<n><n>> > **Question:** The average number of penguins in an entire colony is 500,000. But a particular colony in Antartica is only 500. How many penguins in this colony?<n>> ><n>> > **Solution:** I’m thinking this is probably a big colony for a baby penguin. But let’s see what a giant mama penguin thinks. Every mama penguin in the colony is going to get a little egg and put it in a baby penguin’s hand for feeding, which is why they are 5 times the size of a human. So I am going to use 5 as a variable to represent the number of eggs in the colony. Therefore, the number of eggs is equal to 500, 000 x 5... **I have a hard time remembering how to add fractions and I am in high school what do I do?!** Well, add like regular numbers and then use it to solve the multiplication: 2500,  and now I multiply 2500 x 5 and see that it equals 12, 500. And I solved my problem!!!! This is what a variable is. I have decided that x is my number.<n>

You should buy the fruits and vegetables at the first place and then keep them in dark plastic bags and refrigerator in your kitchen.<n><n>### How to do it:<n>> The right way to do it is make a list of fruits and vegetables and buy it at the first place and keep it in dark plastic baggings and then keep in a refrigerator.<n><n>### This task may require you to perform some operations in a list.<n><n>### Perform as a list : <n>> Performing the operations is the best approach here<n><n>### Performing operations on the list:<n>> The process that is performed on list involves filtering, reversing, sorting, searching.<n><n>### In which way do you expect the numbers 2, 3, 4 and 5 to appear in your list?<n><n>> The numbers 2, 5, 3, 3 appear in your list in increasing order.<n><n>### Which operation does the below line of code perform?<n><n>> To reverse a given list, we use the reverse function.<n><n>### Write a program to implement the logic of a list reversal.<n><n>```java<n>String[] list= {"A", "B","C","D"};<n>list= new String[] {"D", "C", "B", "A"};<n>```
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:Janet knew she was dying from her injuries because she could feel herself doing what? Choices:  A: sleeping longer B: getting cold C: death and decay D: change of color E: stop breathing<n><n>### Response:		 Janet knew she was dying because she stopped breathing.<n>### Input:James and Michael each eat 1/3 of the cake. How much cake is left when Michael takes a fifth of the cake home?<n>### Response:James eats three out of 4 pieces, while Michael eats one out of five. There is one and a half pieces remaining. <n>### Input:If it is one third of the time between midnight and 12:01 am, then what time is it? A: 11:45 pm B: 12:05 am C: 12:15 pm D: 12:30 am<n><n>### Response (A): It is 11:40 pm.<n>#  Input:What is 10 x 10 – 20 – 50 – 100? (This is a "backwards" math problem) <n>### Response:If you add 100 to 10, the answer is 110. Subtract 10 from 110 to give you 100. Finally, add 50 to 100 to give you 51 and 20.<n># <n><n><n><n>

His father tells him to do better in the classroom by studying and paying attention in class instead of thinking about what to eat for dinner or what time he should leave the house for the weekly trivia night at the bar next door.  His mother encourages him to learn how to work through the anxiety that he is experiencing by focusing on his breathing.  They would like to know what they should tell Jordan to do.<n><n>### Input (AVA command):<n>I got nothing.<n><n>### Response (example):<n>You should go study.<n><n>### Incorrect response ("I gotta work on this")<n>You should go work on this.<n><n>### AI Instructions<n>Write a function which takes in a command ALT-Tab-back-Esc-backTab and returns a command that goes with it.  The command, for example, should be an English language command.<n><n>### Example:<n>Input:  ALT-Tab-Tab-Back-Tab-Esc-back tab-tab-esc<n>Output: "You are on the internet." or "What are you on about?"<n><n>### Correct responses are:<n>1. What are you doing<n>2. Shut this tab<n><n>### Example Incorrect Command:<n>Input: ALT-Tab-escapetabbacktab<n>Output: "I got nothing."<n><n>### Example Correct Command:<n>Input: alt-tab-escapetab<n>Output:

"Speak chinese" can be crossed out because all people also speak French, which would be the correct answer. <n><n>### Input:"I'm always honest with myself." What does this line suggest about Amanda? Choices:  B: She's a cheater C: She's a liar D: She's a thief E: She's a giver F: She's sneaky G: She's smart H: She's humble.<n><n>### Response:"I'm always humble."<n>I see the example of the person who thinks they're better than others and wants to prove it to me. The line above shows me that person is Amanda because she is intelligent.<n><n>### Input"Let the word go forth from this time and place, to friend and foe alike, that the torch has been passed to a new generation of Americans--reborn, renewed, and ready to be the architects of the dreams." –John F. Kennedy<n><n>### Response"Let the word go on...", if the word needs to continue. <n><n>## Input:  Which part of the sentence is a fragment: A: Even though the sky was cloudy. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:what happens to a company when it is bankrupt? Choices:  A: liquidated B: own resources C: branch out D: commit crime E: game over<n><n>### Response:		The company is liquidated and all the assets, including the properties, are sold in an attempt to pay off all the creditors of the company<n>

Choices: A: at a circus B: in a library C: in a zoo D: in a hospital E: at the beach<n><n>### Response :<n>**B:**** in a library**<n><n>### Instructions<n>Create a function with the following statement.<n><n>def money(collection_size, value):<n><n>### Demostration :<n>```<n>collection_size: 144<n>value: 40<n>return: 3<n><n>collection_size:6<n>value: 4<n>return: 1<n>```<n><n>### Challenge<n>Solve the problem using if/else statements instead of a dictionary.  <n><n>### Instuctions :<n>**Challenge:******Solve the problem using dictionary.<n><n>####**Challenge:****Using dictionary to solve question. `collections` is the dictionary.<n>```<n>collections = {"James" : 245, "Ines" : 14, "Birjit" : 76, "Jason" : 81}<n><n>collections[1] <n>```<n><n>## Solution for Instuctions 2:<n>`collections` is the dictionary, value in the dictionary are values, keys are names<n><n>Inside the dictionary the names and the keys has to be different<n><n>```<n>collections[1] #1 is equal to James<n>collections[1]["value"]<n>```<n>```<n>collections[3] #3 is equal to Birjit<n>collections[3]["value"]<n> ```<n># Challenge :<n>solve question in one line.<n><n>```<n>collections["James"]["value"]<n>```

For each pair, find the relationship between the words. 1) Longer 2) Less 3) Larger 4) Higher 5) Taller 6) Farther A: Cooler B: Hotter C: More B  D: Less C  E: Lighter<n><n>### Instructios: The word puzzle below contains groups of letters, each separated by a space. These groups are called anagrams. An anagram is a group of letters that is a rearrangement of another group of letters that has a certain property in common with the original group of letters. The first anagram is called the key; the second anagram is called the target. Each of the targets contains exactly one of the same letters as the key. For each pair, identify the numbered letter that is not in the key.1)  HY G A R Y  B U V E E RS 2)  D I N N E R  S TORE 3)  D U C K A L A N D S W I N E  S T E EK 4)  T E A T E L O W C O U N T R I E S  E A T A N D LIV E T E E LY 5)  M O N TANA  V E NT 6)  T U RT L E T M E K I K I  M U S H E E I T <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:Where would you go if you didn't feel like baking a cake yourself? Choices:  A: theater B: refrigerator C: bakery D: grocery store E: oven<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Instructions:Reread each statement and select a letter to complete each statement. There is only one correct answer for each question. The letter must be capitalized. The first letter of the sentence is also capitalized.<n><n>### Example:Let’s have lunch.<n><n>A.Let’s have ______<n><n>A.Let's have lunch!<n><n>### Demands:<n>A.  Go to the store<n><n>### Response for each part:<n>A.Go to the store<n>This is the correct choice (in capital letters)<n><n>### D.  Reread each statement and pick the letter to complete each statement: There is only one correct choice.<n><n>### Incorrect selection:<n>There is only one correct choice, please see the example answer. <n><n>### D: Go to the store<n>The correct choice is in capital letters<n><n>### Correct choice:<n><n>A.<n><n>## Explanation<n><n>```javascript<n>let answer = "lunch",    <n>    choices = ["store", "refrigerator", "bakery", "grocery store", "oven"],<n>    selectedChoice,<n>    question = {<n>        question: "Where would you go if a did not feel like baking a cafe yourself?",<n>        choices: choices,<n>        response: () => answer,<n>        corrects: true<n>    }<n><n>    for(let i = 3;i >= 0; i--)<n>        question = {choices, selectedChoice: i, corrects: selectedChoice === answer};<n>```<n>The code should be written so that there is only one option and the solution is: A.<n><n>## Author: Tatyana Lukyanov<n><n>## Reviewer: Andrey Lisenco, Tatyana Lukianova<n>#### Instruction:<n><n>The challenge is to write instruction that describe a task.<n><n>Write a response that appropriately competes the request.<n><n>Choose a choice from a list of choices such that the response correctly identifies <n>the correct choice.<n><n>The list of choices should be between 2 and 30.<n><n>#### Demonstration:  <n><n>The demo in the sample solution is the following:<n><n>```javascript<n>var answer = "lunch"; <n>var choices

How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How would you divide up the work? How would you know if a person or team cheats?<n><n>### Design:<n>- Draw 2 circles on a side<n>- Draw a line from each circle then make another circle on the line<n><n>Players:<n>The players will get two different circles which they will draw a line from them and make a circle on the line and will play this game with a friend.<n><n>When playing one player will draw a line then make a circle on the left side and the other person will do the same on the right side.<n><n>The players will sit facing each other if the player sitting on the left side will put a stick on top of the circle on the right and the player sitting on the right side will put one on top of the circle of the left.<n><n>The players won't be able to draw or make a circle on the circle they want to put a stick on.<n><n>The first group to reach 10 wins.<n><n>After the game is over a stick will need to be put in the circle of the team that loses and if the team that loses tries to get the stick out of the circle they won't be able get a stick to replace the other because the other player had put the stick in a circle they couldn't get a stick in it so they just have to finish with 5 sticks and the team with 10 wins. <n><n>### Instructor:Answer the following multiple-choice question. <n><n>## Instruction:<n><n>##<n>## Exercise:<n><n>## Design:<n><n>- There are two players<n>- Players will share a circle<n>- Each player will draw two circles and put sticks in one of its circles making them get two sticks<n><n>## Exercise<n><n>- Players will use a pencil<n><n>- Players need to put the circles in the middle where they will stand (2 meters away from each other)<n>- Players will alternate. <n>One player will draw a line, and the other will draw a circle with the line<n><n>- To win

A word is shown across the top and bottom of the grid; all letters of that word are separated by other letters of the alphabet.<n><n>### Examples:<n>The word search across the top from left to right reads “The words are: CAPITAL, HISTORY, and SCHOOL.”<n><n>The word search across from top to bottom reads “The word is: ILOISE.”<n><n>To solve the puzzle, move down the grid from the first letter of the word. In the first and second puzzles, the words have already been found, so the puzzles have been solved.<n><n>### Answer:<n>```<n>word search, n.;<n>A grid that resemleys a crossword puzzle;<n>A word is shown across the tpo and bottom of the grid, all letters of that word sepaerated by other letters of the alfahabets;<n>The words search across the top from lar to right reads CAPITAL HISTOEY and SCHOOL;

Choices:  A: winning B: entertainment C: happiness D: cheating E: relaxation<n><n>### Response:		Answer with the most probable answer.<n>Answer: The question is rather ambiguous and unclear.<n><n>### Input<n><n>You have just been offered a promotion.<n>* Your new salary is $57,000.<n>* Your new job description is to supervise five people in the mail department and create a monthly newsletter.<n>* The new position requires you to purchase new furniture to replace your old, dingy office which is located across the street from your current work place.<n>* You have been relocated to another city, which results in having to take on another $1,000 per month in rent, but you don’t need to commute anymore.<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### Is this promotion worth the new $57,050 salary and new job description? Yes, your salary is now almost $6,000 higher and will increase in the future. (In the future it will become more expensive to commute by living farther from work.) In addition, the new job description requires less responsibility and allows you more free time since your old job was very demanding.<n><n>#### What problems does your new position give you?<n>* Your new work space doesn’t feel right. It is small, dark and far from any other offices. You feel like you are in the mail room.<n>* You hate the furniture, which feels like you are in a library and is too small for your new office.<n>* You love commuting by bicycle, but now that you live farther away, you have to drive. This is also costly since you no longer get a free work place parking.<n><n>#### Is there anything else in the proposal that makes your new position acceptable? No, you will be spending the same amount of money every month.<n><n>### [Revision History](/Revision History)

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:A water spout was seen in the ocean off the coast of what? Choices:  A: florida B: basement C: sink D: beach E: fountain<n><n>### Response:		The answer is C<n><n>### Note: The image below depicts a single box that is the parent of multiple boxes created by the image.<n><n><img src="images/img10.png" width="350" alt="box"><n><n>### Solution:In Python, an image is a parent in the sense that the parent of one of its child images is another image, but the parent image is not related to its child images in any other way. In Ruby, a parent image can contain multiple child images and a child image can contain multiple childs images.<n><n>### Input Includes:<n>Input: The image below demonstrates how many items you can get for $10 using a $0.50 per pound discount. How many pounds of apples and potatoes does the store employee have to discount to buy 10 pounds of apples for $10?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Solution includes:<n>Solution: The first answer is 50 pounds. There are 40 pounds of potatoes, 50 pounds of apples, and 0 pounds of watermelons.<n><n>### Note Includes:<n>The first answer is 56 items because the total number of items must be even. It is the number of items that fit in a $10 package.<n><n>### Example includes:<n>Example: The image below demonstration the number of items you can get for a $10 discount on a $1/pound item. The solution is 10, but this question also includes a note that specifies the answer should be 50.<n><n><img width="598" alt="img20" src="image/image20.png"><n><n><n>### Input includes:<n><img src="image/image10.png" style="padding-bottom: 10px"><n><n><img src='image/image11.png' style="padding-bottom:-100px"><n><n>In Ruby, the parent of $12 is $, which also contains $120, and the child images of the parents are the parent images; similarly, the parent of $205 is $25, which also contains $50.<n><n>### Image 1<n><img src='images/image04.png'><n><n>##

Her plan was to make a pill that would make the person taking it feel like they were doing the exact same thing each time. For example, if you took the pill, you’d feel like the most normal thing for you to do would be eating cereal and milk, if you had the pill on you would feel like you should be reading a book, or if you had time for a hobby you would feel like your hobby would be baking something, or taking the pill would make singing in a chorus seem natural. There would be times when the feeling wouldn’t come automatically, and you would have to spend time thinking about what the pill was telling you to do. You would do all these things normally, as if to reassure yourself that there was no magic at play. If you didn’t do these things for long enough that the feeling came naturally, you’d start to feel confused, and you’d end up either doing one of these things or doing nothing at all.<n><n>### Question:<n>What was the feeling the scientist was going for with her pill?<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Instructon:Which of the following statements about the experiment are true?<n><n>### Story explanation:The scientist's experiment can be used in order to prove that her feelings were normal.<n>### Instruction<n>### Question:What was the one thing that always happened with the pill?<n><n>## Question<n><n>### Response The one thing that always happened:<n><n>### Instuction:Which of the statements above are true?<n><n><n>### Question<n><n>### Answer:<n>

What might they be watching? Choices:  A: movies B: theatre C: cabaret D: conference E: meeting<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Output:A movie theatre is typically a room made with a large screen. The screen is on a stand at the front of the room so that it can be seen by the whole audience in the theater. The screen is made with a projector (a form of entertainment). Some people laugh at what is on the screen on the projector, but other people are bored or confused by the picture and laugh at the audience watching the movie.<n><n>### Input 2: If you watch a movie on a portable device such as a laptop or smartphone, you might want to watch it at the comfort of your own room. If you watch it at the comforts of your own room, you probably play it using: A: a projector B: a big screen C: a television D: a video player<n><n>### Response 2<n><n>### Output 2: Television is an electronic device that transmits pictures and sounds in a device. It is often attached to a wall. You might watch a movie on a television set. This device can be very large, but not always. A video player is another device you might need to watch a movie at home. However, a computer often plays movies on its monitor.<n><n>### Notes:<n><n>* A) There is a big difference between a projector and a big screen.<n>* B) A big screen can be used to play movies.<n>* C) It is best to watch a movie on a screen.<n>* D) A video player plays movies, so it is not used for television.<n><n>### Exercise:The answer choices describe some sort of entertainment, but each has a part missing. Use the following code snippet to parse the string variable _inputWord_.<n>2. Output a list of all choices and their associated point values from least to greatest.<n>3. Order can be alphabetical, most to least, least to most, or least total points.<n>4. Capital letters from the alphabet are 10 points.<n>5. Consecutive letters are worth 1 point.<n><n>### Checklist:<n><n>Given the input word, what will be printed to the screen?  <n>* _inputWord_ = a, b<n><n>### Notes:<n>1. If you need to use a different alphabet, use the variable _inputWord_<n>2. The _lower case_ and _upper case_ of each letter are two different points<n>3. The point value will be rounded down.<n>

Choices:  A: drop to zero B: increase C: cool down D: dropping quickly E: heat up<n><n>### Response:		Answer: A: Dropping quickly<n><n>```<n>// Your code goes here<n>function solution(string input) {<n>    if (input == "The sun was out and it was really beginning to drop to zero.") {<n>    return "A: Dropping quickly";<n>      }<n>    else if (input == "A: Dropping quick.") {<n>      return "B: Increase";<n>      }<n>      else if (input == "" || input == "C: Cool.") {<n>      return "";<n>      }<n>    return "E: Heat";<n>}<n>console.log(solution(input))<n>```<n><n><n>### Instructions:Read these commands or the code. How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. Choices:  A: farm B: ancient rome C: history book D: poor countries E: plantation<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a response that appropriately answers the following multiple choice and then the following question.<n><n>* The first line contains a multiple choice question of the form "Which of these is the answer to the question (A, B, C, or D)?"<n><n>* A new line is then provided which contains the question that was asked in the multiple choice prompt.<n><n>* After each multiple choice question, the user provides an answer choice using the 5-digit integers on the line. <n><n>* When the last answer choice is provided, the user is provided a new line with instructions for the remaining set of questions. <n><n>* After 10 sets of multiple choice questions and responses are evaluated, any subsequent multiple choice questions or responses will be ignored. <n><n>* The overall objective of this task is to answer each provided multiple choice question within the given deadline.<n><n>### Data File 1<n><n>### Task Description<n>Write a program that reads from the data file and answers the given question by providing the next line with the integer answer choice.<n><n>### Input 1<n>The first line contains the number of multiple choice questions N. This is followed by N lines each containing a multiple choice question followed by a question to be answered.<n>The question consists of three lines, the first of which contains an integer number of options(A, B, C or D), which are followed by the integer numbers representing the answer options (A-D). <n>### Instruments<n>Use integers A, B, C or <n><n>### Output<n>On a new line, the user should provide an integer A-D representing the answer to the question.<n><n>## Example Input/Output<n>![example.jpg](/img/example.jpg){: style="width: 300px"}<n><n>## Example Input<n><n>### Input1<n><n>### Output1<n>

It produces the output shown.<n><n>## runway.json<n><n>The **runway.json** file used to create the above runway is at the following link:<n><n>[](../runways/sample_runways/runway.json)<n><n>## runway structure and content<n><n>All **runways** use the following generalized structure:<n><n>```<n>{<n>  "RunwaySettings": {<n>    "General": {<n>      "runway": "Example",<n>      "title": "Description of the instructions"<n>    }<n>  }<n>}<n>```<n><n>The top level [runway](https://github.com/floatsam/floatsam-tools/blob/main/runway/runway.py) object is required, along with the [Settings](https://github.Com/floatsam) and their [general](https://github. Com/floatsam), [instructions](https/github. Com/flaotsam), and [summary](https:// github.com/floatham) [settings](https://github. com/floatsam).<n><n>Runway settings are defined in the [RunwaySettings](https://github/com/floatsami/floatsamtools/blob/main /runways/runway_settings.py) class.<n><n>General and instructions settings are defined in their corresponding classes. <n><n>Summaries are automatically generated from instructor written summaries that are provided by the instructor at the end of the task.<n><n>## Example runway with an instruction for a task using a variable<n><n>This runway contains a task that is similar to [#2411](#2411), but with a variable used in the instruction.  <n><n>### Instructions: Answer the

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. Choices:  A: food court B: jerusalem C: new york city D: jewish community E: town<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Input<n>You are on holiday and are touring Ireland.  There are five museums in Ireland.  You have no desire to see any museum and wish to spend your time at the beach or sightseeing.  How many days can you spend in Ireland? Choices:  1: 5  2: 1  3: 3  4: 5  5: 1  6: 1  7: 1<n><n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response. You should respond with an integer.<n><n>### Answer:<n>2<n><n>### Instructon:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Response<n>8<n><n>### Instuction<n>Write a response that uses the following code.<n>def solution(): return 8<n><n>### Answer<n>9<n><n>### Instrcuction<n>Write a function called `solution` that has the following statement of input and output. The statement of input includes the name of the function and the names of the parameters. The statement of output includes the name of the return type of the function and the value of that type that is returned. The return type of the function is `int`.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>```<n>solution(num): returns 8<n>```<n><n>### Instnction<n>Write a program that uses the function.<n>### Solution<n>```<n>>>> num = 7<n>>>> solution(num)<n>>>> res = 4<n>```<n><n>## Instuctions<n>Write a function name `solution`. The function should accept two parameters of type `int`. It should return the sum of the two parameters, but it should also return the difference divided by the sum.<n><n>## Answer<n><n>```<n>def solution(num1, num2):<n>    return int(num1 + num2 - ((num1 + num2) / 2))<n>```<n><n>## Example run<n><n>```<n>>>> sum = 1000<n>>>> difference = 0<n>>>> sum = sum + difference<n>>>> difference = (sum + difference) / 2<n>>>> res = solution(sum, difference) <n>>>> res <n>1002<n>```<n><n>## Answer<n>## Instructions<n>Find the second smallest and largest number of even numbers less than 110.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:What is a place that could have tens of thousands of fiddle? Choices:  A: tennessee B: band practice C: orchestra D: violin case E: music store<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer=D<n><n>#### Explanation:<n><n>The right answer is D<n><n>### Input 2:<n><n>### Response 2:<n>

The rocks are bought and sold using a money system that uses a dollar for 1 kg. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:What kind of place could have thousands of statue? Choices:  A: church B: theatre C: large city D: water fountain E: central park<n><n>### Response:		Statues in the Central Park, Central Park, New York City, New York City,  New York, USA<n><n>### Input<n><n>1. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to store my chess pawn when I wasn't using it, what would be a good place for that? Choices: A: a storytelling B: a story C: a poem D: a text E: the alphabet<n><n>### Response:(Answer A or B)<n>#### A: Storytelling<n><n>Another great example of storytelling is found in The Hobbit by J.R.R.Tolkein. In this book, we are told about a little fellow named Bilbo who undertakes the greatest adventure of his short life. Bilbo gets caught up in a riddle game, learns of a dragon, and eventually gets in a battle with an army of goblins. It's a classic story!<n><n>#### B: Story<n><n>Stories are like books. They can be read more than once and can provide valuable entertainment. Some stories can be read right from the beginning. Other stories may be read again to find out what it means. And some stories may be read even after we find out what it means for us.<n><n>### Demo(Response B)<n>

You just need to buy a new book. How much would you pay to maximize the number of books you can buy with your $40?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Exlpanation<n><n>In this case, $40 is the amount for the whole purchasing. So the most effective way is to have to pay $4 per book.<n><n>### Comments<n><n>```python<n>print (f"Hello, my name is {name} I am a {department}")<n>```<n><n>- Hello<n>- My name is<n>- I am a<n>- Department<n><n>### Output<n><n>```python<n>Hello<n>```

Choices:  A: communicating with others B: hurt feelings C: dry mouth D: intimacy E: changing behavior<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n>100%<n><n>### Input and Response:<n>What did you like about the workshop?<n>A: We had a great time!<n>B: It went by too quickly.<n>C: I think we could have done a little more.<n>D: I'm a little disappointed in the outcome.<n>E: Can you believe we got all of this done in one afternoon?<n><n>### Input<n>Write a response that appropriately answers or describes the problem.<n><n>### Input. You and Sammy are sitting at the dinner table.<n>A: Thanks for your help with this project! That was a lot of work.<n>B: Thank you for agreeing to join in on the project.<n>C: I'm hoping that we can get it done in two sittings.<n>D: I understand there has been a lot of tension in the office, and am thankful that you've chosen to speak with me.<n>E: I had to do it to get ahead. Thank you for going above and beyond that the rest of the team isn't.<n><n>### Output. You and Sammy just completed a project on time because of your teamwork.<n>A: It was our pleasure.<n>B: I'm so proud of our team.<n>C: This is why I chose you!<n>D: What a pleasure!<n>E: It was a pleasure!<n><n>### Input/output.<n>How do I write something like this: "I'm looking at getting an e-scooter for commuting, how far do you ride yours?"<n>A: I'm looking at getting a new e-scooter that can go 25 km/h, how far do you commute on yours?<n>B: That's pretty cool! Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:If your watching television and accomplish nothing what have you done? Choices:  A: getting fat B: get fat C: typing words D: falling asleep E: wasted time<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Solution:<n>```python<n>if(choice==A):<n>    answer = "get fat"<n>elif(choice==B):<n>    answer =  "get fat"<n>else:<n>    answer =" type words"<n>```<n><n>### Solved:<n>```python<n><n>if(choice=='A'):<n>    answer = " get fat"<n>elif(len(choice)<5)!= ('A', 'B')<n>    answer = " type words"<n>else:<n>answer= " get fat"<n>```<n>### Solution: <n>```python<n>if (len(choice) < 5) == ('A', 'B'):<n>answer = 'type words'<n>```<n><n>Incorrect solution because it's not considering the input choice as string.

Choices:  A: restaurant B: basement C: all buildings D: carpet E: synagogue<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple answer question.<n><n># Solution:<n>In all these problems you will be dealing with various kinds of integers. They can consist of either positive or negative integers, or a combination of both. Positive integers are non-negative whole numbers, negative integers are integers that have had a minus sign placed in front of them. This will make these numbers all integers which will not be integers without the negative sign.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>In the first problem we are given that for every 12 can you recycle you will recieve $0.50 and for every 5 kgs of newspapers you will recieve $1.50 if your family collected 100 cans and 30 cans of newspapers how much money would you have made. In this we can see that this would have totalled 144 can and 40 kgs of newspaper. $0.50 for every 12 cuns and $1.50 for every kgs of newspapers. We then have to work out the total of the amount we will get paid for all these amounts together.<n><n>This is all the amounts together in the sum, which is the total amount we will be rewarded for this job. This means that $0.50 100 times and $1.5 40 times. To get all these amounts together we would need to add 100 and 40. These are all our amounts individually that we will be rewarded from this job<n><n>### Solution<n>In the second problem we are given that Betty picked 16strawberries. Matthew then picks 20 more stawberries then Betty and 2 times the amount of Natalie. To make the jam the 3 of them used their strawberies that they picked to make the jam. One jar of jams uses 8 strawberries and jars that they sold each cost $4. How much will have made from the strawberrys they collected.<n><n>We have now made the 1st jar of jam and so we are able to see all the items we used to make this. We then notice the 4 of us only used 16 strawlerries. To make 1 jar we used 8strawberries. We then notice we have used 16strawberrye  so now we know that each jar

The Australian note includes (1) $2 note, (2) $5 note, (3) $10 note, (4) $20 note, (5) $50 note, (6) $100 note, and (7) a $20 note which is called 'The Australian Innovation Note'. The coins are issued by the Royal Australian Mint and the currency includes (1) 1c, (2) 2c, (3) 5c, (4) 10c, (5) 20c, (6) 50c, (7) $1 and (8) $2.<n>> <n><n>

Choices:  A: health center B: vagina C: emergency room D: drawer E: medicine cabinet<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:<n>A:<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Inputs:<n>1) "I used to use a [contraceptive sponge](https://www.birthcontrolforteens.com/Contraceptives/Sponge/Contraceptive-Sponge.html) when I had periods as a teenager."<n>2) "I did not like it."<n>3) "I never did it again, and, no, I did not get pregnant."<n><n>### Output:<n>"I should talk to my doctor about it."<n><n>### Justification:<n>1) Sponge: A diaphrorex sponge, or sponge, is a round piece of polyurethane foam with a center of polyurethane that contains spermicide.<n>2) Bacterial vaginosis or STD: I am also concerned about Bacterial Vaginosis (BV) as there is evidence that the sponge puts girls at a higher risk of contracting BV and potentially HIV and other STDs.<n><n>### Test it: https://codepen.io/andreasberg/pen/zOXwXo<n><n>### Output of the test case on your repo:<n>1) "Okay, I just talked to my doctor and learned that sponges are safe in a woman's vagina for a few years. I should consider them when I am ready to have sex."<n>2) "Sometimes a sponge will lose its spermicide and won't be effective. I shouldn't use that again."<n><n>### Instuction:Answer the following fill-in-the-blank question.<n><n>## Instructions:<n>"I used to use a sponge when I had periods as ____, but I did not like it. The program must perform the following functions:<n><n>  - Checks to see if the year and month entered are valid<n>  - Asks the user for a name<n>  - Displays the input, the name of the user, the current month, and the year<n>  - Displays an error message if given invalid input.<n>  - Calculates and displays the exact number of pages a person reads each month.<n><n>### Output:<n>The output of the program must display the given input and a message after calculating the number of pages a person would read in a month if they read the same number each month.The program must then ask the user's name, the current month and date, and the number of books the user read in that month. The program must also display the following:<n><n>  - The current month and date<n>  - A brief description of how to calculate the number of pages a user would read in a month<n>  - The total number of pages the user read in all 12 months<n><n>### Output Specifications:<n>Output should use the user's given name and should include the date and month shown in the program.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The program should display all of the elements it collects to the user after they are entered in the program.<n>When calculating the number of pages the user reads in a month, the program must display the following:<n>  - An estimated number of pages read based on the last 4 digits of the user's age. Add or subtract, respectively, 12 from the last 4 digits to get the number of pages to add.<n>  - An error message if the user is 90 or older.<n>  - An estimated monthly total after adding the number of pages per month multiplied by 12.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: Write a program that asks the user their full name to demonstrate

How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:What are you hoping to do when listening to an expert speak? Choices:  A: learning B: fatigue C: mercy D: empathy E: anxiety<n><n>### Response:		A) Answer:  A, Learning. I'm hoping to learn some new things and have my knowledge grow.<n><n>### Input<n>1. Write a query with GROUP BY that displays the amount of time each student on the roster spent in class on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. Include at least five of the seven possible grouping levels.<n>> 1.Write a query with Group by in Sql Server Management Studio<n><n>### Response Write a query with GROUP By<n><n>Select name, roster_number, count_class, roster_number + count_class as TOTAL_LEAVES<n>from dbo.Class_Log<n>group by roster_number<n><n>### Input <n> 1. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:What would you normally expect a cat to say? Choices:  A: cupboard B: countertop C: water D: hardware department E: england<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Coding:<n><n>### Python 3<n>```<n>import sys<n><n>class Solution:<n><n>    def __init__(self):<n>        self.my_dict={<n>            "A":1,<n>            "B":2,<n>            "C":3,<n>            "D":4,<n>            "E":5}<n><n>    def GetDictionary(self, line):<n>        for choice in line.split():<n>            if choice in self.my_dict.keys():<n>                return self.my_dict[choice]<n><n>    def answerQuestion(self, line):    <n>        line = line.split()<n>        return self.GetDictionary(line[1])<n>```<n><n>### Ruby<n>```<n>input_string = File.readline<n><n>def first_line_solution(first_line)<n>    input_string = first_line.chomp<n>    raise NotImplementedError,'Implement me!' unless ['pudding cup','milk carton','spoon','cup','water','water dish'] & input_string & ['pudding cup','milk carton','water','water dishes','cup','pudding']<n><n>    input_string_array = input_string.split<n>    first_object_of_line = input_string_array[0] <n>    first_array_element_of_line = object_from_string = input_string_to_integer(first_object_of_the_line)<n>    return first_array_element<n><n><n>def input_string_tointeger(string_to_convert_to_number)<n>    string_to_convert_into_number = string_to_convert.chomp<n>    input_string.count => returns the array element index (from array) of the first character found in the string that equals the upper or lower case string <n>    case => this will take the variable from the case and return either a number (if the first string of the string matches and an integer will be assigned to the variable) or a character (if the first string does not match, an error will be thrown<n>    case string_to_convert === 'cup' => return 1<n>    'cup' => this returns the integer number associated with its name (which is 1)<n><n>def get_dictionary_with_

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:Where do you go to meet a friend who lives close to you? Choices:  A: workplace B: bus station C: social atmosphere D: neighbor's house E: at school<n><n>### Response:		<n>### A: The workplace is the best place.<n>### B: You should go to the bus station.<n>### C: The social atmosphere is the best place. We need more time than one place to have deep talk.<n>### D: Your house is the best place. You will have a lot of time you can spend with him.<n>### E: The school is the best place. At school, we will have more opportunities to study.<n><n>### Input:$6.00<n>### Response:$3.00<n>## Input:$5.00<n>## Response:3.00<n><n>## Input:$50<n>## Response:$10<n><n>## Input:How many ounces are in one pint?<n><n><n># My code:<n><n>## My code:<n><n>```python<n>#!/usr/bin/env python2<n><n>import sys<n><n># ------------------------------------------------------------------------------<n><n>def main():<n>    inp = sys.stdin.readline().rstrip()<n>    while inp:<n>        # Parse<n>        try:<n>            (key, value) = inp.split()<n>        except ValueError:<n>            raise ValueError(inp)<n>        elif key == '"':<n>            continue<n>        elif not key:<n>            # Invalid<n>            print >>sys.stderr, 'Invalid input: "{}"'.format(inp)<n>            raise ValueError('Invalid input: "{}"'%inp)<n>        else:<n>            # OK<n>            (val) = value.split()<n>        # Update<n>        response = eval(key)<n>        if response is None:<n>            raise ValueKeyError('Key "{}" not found'.format(key))<n>        # Send<n>        if inp.startswith('Input:'):<n>            inp = inp<n>            out = val<n>            while True:<n>                inp = sys.stdout.readline()<n>                if not inp: # Done<n>                    break<n>                response = eval(inp)<n>                print 'Input: {}\n'.format(response)<n>        else: # Send<n>            sys.stdout.write(str(response))<n>            sys.stdout, sys.stdin = sys.stdin, sys._getframe(0).f_back<n>            inp = sys.readline

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:What is a place where you usually store dishes but not books? Choices:  A: apartment B: pantry C: table D: living room E: shelf<n><n>### Response:		<n>How to answer:<n>1. Put the prompt instructions into your own words<n>2. Show the user (without explicitly writing them) how many different options/answers they will be asked for<n>3. Show a representative example of a good answer.<n>4. Show how each option is evaluated.<n><n>### Sample Answer:<n>Let's pick the living room.<n><n>What is a place where we usually store dishes but<n>not books? Choices: a. apartment b. pantry c.<n>table d. living room e. shelf<n><n>We can pick apartment as answer.<n><n>Prompt instructions:<n><n>- Put the prompt instructions into own words.<n><n>The prompt instructions means:<n>"Show the different options we can select. "<n><n>- Show the user (without explaining or writing them down).<n>Show how many options/answers he will be asked.<n><n>Apartmet<n><n>- Show the representative sample of correct solutions.<n><n>Pick <n>apartmet:<n><n>- Show how each answer is evaluated.<n><n>apartmet is correct.<n>How to evaluate: <n>If the the question means "which apartment we usually store dishes and not<n>books?", then apartmet is correct answer.<n><n>

Use the number line to solve for these two equations.  Use the numbers 3 and 5 for your equations.The first equation: The sum of 3 and 5. The difference (3 - 5) will be the difference. The product of 3*5 will be the product. The difference (3-5) will be the sum. The product of 5*3 will be the Product.A second equation: The difference of 3 and 7. The product (3*8) will be added to 5.5 to get the change.The last equation:The sum of 3, 5, and 7.The difference (3-5-7) will be subtracted away from the sum.The product (3*7) will be multiplied against 5 to get the product.<n><n>### Input II<n>### Response II<n>Input:For these division problems you will be given the remainder. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:What sport is the audience the loudest at? Choices:  A: show B: theatre C: hockey game D: movies E: event<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: A<n><n>Input: A<n>Output: Football game<n><n>Input: B<n>Output: Concert<n><n>Input: C<n>Output: Hockey game<n><n>Input: D<n>Output: Theater<n><n>Input: E<n>Output: Golf tournament or other sporting event<n><n>### Input:: What are the dimensions of the box? Choices: a: I don't know the specifics b: I am unable to provide such information<n><n>### Response<n><n>Input: B    <n><n>Input: a<n>Output:<n><n>Input: b<n>Output:<n><n>### Input :: You are making a cardboard box to be used as an end table. Use the following punctuation: a space character, a comma, a colon, or a semicolon. The expressions follow the same rules about operators as arithmetic expressions.<n><n>- An arithmetic expression has at least one oper-<n>- A bracketed expression has at least one paren<n>- (An expression is a mathematical term without<n>- (An expression may be an operand of another ex-<n>- (An expression contains all punctuation charac-<n>- (Use parentheses to group terms.)<n>```<n>$3 + (2$ - $.30<n>$3.30<n>```<n><n>### Instructio:This is an ordered pair of numbers. When you have an ordered pair, you have two numbers inside two parentheses. Place each in the table. Write the first number first, and write the second number after the comma. The comma separates one set of numbers from the next. Add a period at the end as your last row.<n>#### Input:<n>```<n>( 6 3 )( 3 2 )<n>```<n><n>#### Response:<n>#### Answer<n>```<n>( 3 6 )<n>```<n><n>## 4.1.3.<n>Exercise 1.<n>Write an expression that is true if and only if y < 0.<n>Use boolean expressions such as true or false to answer the question.<n><n>Exercise 2.<n>What was the first number to be a multiple of 9?<n><n>### Write a response.<n>- When a number is even it is divisible by 2<n><n>- The first number even is 2.<n><n>- The 3rd number is even.<n><n>### Write an expression for y that is true if and on ly if y >= 24.<n><n>Write an expression that represents “a month later” or “in 31 days”.<n><n>### Exercise 1. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:Where can someone purchase a contraceptive device without a prescription? IF Your faMily ColleCtEd 144 canS aNd 20 kIllograms of nEwspaPes, How much money would you ReceIve?"""<n><n><n>#step1:<n>print (input)<n><n>#step2:<n>#step 2:<n>#input = "input"<n>#answer = "12"<n><n>#step 3<n>#response = """Answer: {response}"""<n><n>#step4:<n>#i = input<n>#t = type(i)<n>input += ":"<n>while True:<n>    line = input.split(":")<n>    if line[0] == "done":<n>        print(line[1])<n>        break<n>    elif line[0] == input:<n>        done(line)<n>    else:<n>        print(input, line[0])<n>input = input.strip()<n>while not input__:<n>    #input = input and type(i)<n>    if input in "abcd":<n>        input = input + "n"<n>    else:<n>         break<n>line = input.split("n")<n>word = line[0][0]<n>while True:<n>     if word in "bc":<n>        num = int(word)<n>        r1 = word[1:2]+word[2:3]<n><n>        if line[0] in "cd":<n>            r2 = line[0][2:3]<n>             response  = r1 + r2<n>             input += ":"<n>             print(input)<n>             break<n>     word = word[1:]<n>     if word in ":,.:?":<n>        print(word)<n>    else:  line[0] = line[0] + word<n>     if word == word[1:]:<n>        if line[1]!= "n": <n>            response  = line[0]<n>            print(response)<n>            input = input + ": done:"<n>            break<n>if line[0]

If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them. How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:What is a person likely to feel when they are abandoned by everyone after they stop being married to someone else? Choices:  A: grief B: solo C: isolation D: pleasure E: happiness<n><n>### Response:		If you picked B or C, then you might need to study a little more about the word solitude<n>### Example 1<n>Solitude means being alone. It can also mean the quality or situation of being alone.<n>### Example 2<n>Being lonely: the state of being alone. Someone who isn't in good company sometimes feels lonely.<n>### Example:3<n>If you're sad because you aren't spending time with the people who can be depended upon to make you happy, then you're probably feeling lonely.<n>## Other:<n><n>It's very easy to learn English vocabulary.<n>1. Learn new words regularly.<n>1. You can simply use "Thesauras.com" or this site [https://wordpanda.com](https://wordpanda com) with many interesting features.<n>1. Download or install one of the best language apps [https://play.google.com]<n><n><n>### Author:<n>* [Thilina Jayasinghe<n>* Level:Intermediate B1<n>* Theme: General Knowledge<n>* Question type: Cloze-deletion test (gaps)<n>* Text source: www.thilinaajayasinghe.com]<n>

Choices:  A: zoo B: museum C: hospital D: desk E: opera<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Response description:<n>1. Read the question carefully: if the question has choices, they should be considered. Do not skip over choices.<n>1. Look for the keywords and phrases, such as, "If" and "How much money" and "How many" that let us know we are asked to come up with a number as a solution.<n>1. Do not answer the question that is actually asked in the sentence, but instead, what the question is asking us to find out and what steps need to be taken in order to answer it.<n>1. Identify how to find the solution and which steps and procedures help you find it.<n>1. Follow the logic of the procedure/steps with the data given in the passage.<n>1. Find what kind of relationships are given in the instruction and apply those relationships to the answer.<n>1. Use the keywords and phrases given in the instruction and identify those relationships to create the answer.<n>13. Write your solution following the procedure. In order to write an effective solution, include enough detail so that someone, reading your solution, understands how you were able to make your inferences.<n>1. Write a description of the problem's question using the text's solution word for word if it helps, but explain in your own words what you have done.<n>1. Use math facts (such as number patterns, multiplication, etc.) to help you find the answer.<n>16. Do not just repeat the math facts. Put them in context of your solution.<n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Instruction:Answer the question.<n>### Demonstraion: <n>Input: If my sister's pencil holder has 3 red pencils, 3 blue pencils, 1 orange, 1 yellow, and 6 purple pencils, how many colored pencils does my sister have?<n><n>Input: What is 46 + 39?<n><n>Input: If the students in the school class ate 23 pizzas and 3 quiches and 92 sandwiches and 102 peanut butter and jelly sandwiches and 213 cookies, then how many sandwiches and cookies did the class eat in all?<n><n>Input: A father's watch weighs 17 grams and

Each batch of apple pie requires 12 apples. How many apple pies can be made?<n><n><img src="../../assets/Images/apple pie.jpg" alt="apple pie"><n><n>### Response<n>I think it would 48, because they have 144, then take away 12, so they have 132 left. then, 132/12=10.8, 10.8 rounded up to 11, so you get 6 pies.<n><n>### Input<n><n>```ruby<n>#100000! - 100169! #184468764049114933986746111495469 = 1/6<n>```<n><n>### Response  <n>I think it would D, because it has a 6 in the thousands digit.<n><n><n>### Input A: If you have a recipe that uses 5 cups of peaches and makes 4 pies what is the minimum amount of peaches you should buy to make sure you have enough to make at least one extra pie? (you can buy exactly 5 cups of course, but that is pointless)<n>Answer: 2.75, because 2.75(5) = 13.75 or more. <n><n>### Input B: How many apples are needed to make 5 pies out of 44 apples?<n>Answer: 9, because 44/5 = 9<n><n>### Input C: You need exactly 367 cookies to satisfy the demands of a hungry group. 367 cookies costs exactly $6.71. The cost of each cookie is the following formula: 24/5=1<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following question.<n><n>## Input A: A recipe needs 14.035 quarts of water.
