Choices:  B: good health <n><n>### Response :<n><n>-If you could only decide to choose one, your health is more important than your wealth.<n>-If you're able to have both, your health is more essential than money.<n>-As there are too many healthy people around, the correct response is B.<n>-Because wealthy individuals always make the most money, choosing C is not a wise decision.<n><n>### Response<n><n>When there is a dispute/conflict, you always want to look for a solution instead of leaving it unresolved. You should make this decision.<n><n>## What should you do if you lose your house keys?<n><n>You can't rely on your house keys to get about or open any of the spaces inside your house if you find that you've forgotten where they are. While you could contact a locksmith, that may be expensive and time-consuming. Luckily, there are some relatively easy ways of fixing the problem.<n><n>#### The first thing to do is to try and remember where it is.<n><n>If you left it in your car or at work, you could always go and look. This should be simple enough unless the car is very messy with things being moved about and your workplace is too big.<n><n>#### Search for the keys<n>If you still cannot find your keys, you will need to go through everything to prevent yourself from losing the same thing twice. This can take a long time, so make sure you leave yourself plenty of time if you go this route.<n><n>#### The second option is to contact a locksmith if all else fails.<n><n>You should be able to have fresh keys made relatively

Create a virtualenv in this directory and activate it by following the instructions in the [virtualenv website](https://virtualenv.pypa.io/en/stable/userguide/installation.html)<n>2. Install the required pip packages<n>```bash<n>pip install -r requirements.txt<n>pip install -e.<n>```<n>2. Run the server<n>```bash<n>python server.py<n>```<n>3. When you get to the server page in your browser, you can add students, tutors and subjects<n><n>### Notes<n>Tutors can access the website by going to `localhost:4000`.  <n>Students can access the webiste by choosing any of the three access links.<n>

How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. Choices:  A: employment B: frustration C: stress D: working hard E: love<n><n>### Response:		<n>### **Your code**<n><n>### **Expected Output**<n><n>### Important information <n><n>In this task, you'll need to:<n><n>- Create a loop to iterate the desired number of times<n>- Print a string, including a for/while/do statement and a while statement or statement in a for loop<n>- Include two user prompts<n>- Display a menu for selecting an item<n>- Calculate and display a result<n>- If a user requests an increase in the number of repetitions, calculate and display the increase<n>- If a user wants to exit the loop, terminate it<n>- Include an “Exit” option in the menu to quit the program<n>- Print an announcement that the program is ending<n><n>### How to complete the task<n><n>- This task is a simple way to get students used to the idea of a loop. There's not a whole lot of instructions, so you can assume they'll start with the prompts. The prompts ask for the number of times each option should repeat. They'll first repeat that number and then increase the number of repetitions every time. They'll end it once a user decides to quit.<n>- They'll probably print each command line prompt (“How many times should each command repeat?”) using the `print()` command.<n>- Then, they'll print each of the menu options (“Please make your choice. What would you like to do?”), using the `print()` and `echo()` commnds (the `echo` command is the same, but the `print()` command sends to the console).<n>- If they get a valid response, such as 3 or 4, they'll execute the corresponding prompt command (with `for` commands or the `repeat` keyword, respectively). The `repeat` keyword simply restores the loop to its original state after it's done iterating.<n>- After the loop is restored back to its original state, they can determine the next action (which will depend on which menu item was selected).<n>- They'll find the end value of each repeat command by either subtracting the number previously printed, or by adding the number printed after `repeat` in other cases.<n><n>### Example<n><n>To see an example of the task, see the [example](examples.md).<n>

Use at least 3 different sentence types (commands, explanations, and instructions) to tell the reader how to perform the task.<n><n>```<n>### Instruction for Task A Answer the following multiple choice question:<n>### What is the main difference between a baker and a cook?<n><n>### Demoration : <n>### Input: What is the main difference in their jobs? Matthe<n>### Answer: She picked more strawberries.<n><n>```<n><n>### Input1: What do you love to do but you can do as well as doing your school work?<n><n>### Answer: Writing stories, drawing, or playing video games.<n><n>### Input 2: Do you love to explore interesting things at the library?<n><n>### Output:<n>### Answer:Yes <n><n>### Instructions for task B: You are going to write a response for this task.<n>### Instruction: Input: How many days can a person be away from home for work without filing a resignation? He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:The wind tore off the shingles, what was the wind like? Choices: <n>> A: win the championship<n>> B: get to the finals<n>> C: give it their all<n>> D: do not go home without getting something<n>><n>> Choices: <n><n>> A: win championship<n><n>> B: get team<n><n>> C: be successful<n>> D: get<n><n>A: win championship > B: get team<n>C: be successful > C: get to the finalist<n>D: get > A: win champion<n><n>### Input3: <n>>In baseball, what is a hit? Choice: <n>> A increase.<n><n>### Response2a: In response to the instruction, “Write a response that appropriately addresses the request. A response that appropriately complets the request, ” you must write a response with a sentence that answers the question. You may not answer the question with a question (“Does the question have an answer?”), a command (“Do the answer the question!”) Or a short summary (“What does the question say?”)<n><n>If the question that you are asked is “What number?” then you must give an answer to what number. If what you type is “Does the question have an Answer,” then your response would be inappropriate for the instruction, because it is not possible to write ““what number? does this question have and answer?”<n><n>I have found that students often use commands, questions, or a short summary to try to communicate that they are attempting to answer the question. This is not a valid response to the instruction: Write a complete sentence in response that appropriately complects the request.<n><n>The best response to the instruction:Write a response that

Which letters form the second and third factors?<n><n>### Solution If we have 4 letters in the first term, then it must be 3 letters to keep it equal.<n>If the 4th letter is i and i=1, then we have 3 letters.<n>if it has to be exactly 4 letters then the first word can't be birch or brich.<n>so since 4=4, the only remaining words are brick and rich.<n>### Input The sum of five consecutive integer numbers is 15. If we are going to pick any element from these 5 then we need to use nested if else where we can write as many if and else if else cases.

I used the formula to count the 2: 2 = 8 <n><n>## Input 3<n><n>In a survey, six out of 10 people like a salad of green leaf lettuce, arugula, and sliced tomato. 11 out of 14 people prefer to drown their salad in ranch dressing. 18 out of 29 people would want a baked potato with that same salad. I subtracted the the groups that like that salad and get 167-136-6 = 5<n><n><n>## Input<n><n>11, 13, 34, 38, 51, 65, 89, and 148. <n><n>## Request<n>The number and sum of each pair<n><n>## Response<n>I subtracted those with the same number and sum then I went from the smallest number to largest and I found the difference between each

When answering questions, always choose the first letter of the first word (except for this one)<n>2. Choose the words that you think will make you think<n>3. Read the whole question first, and choose the first letter of each word in the question. <n><n># How To Pass This Training Session<n><n>1. 10% memorization<n>2. 35% Reading Questions Correctly<n>3. 50% Repeat the Questions Correctly<n><n># Examples Of Questions<n>*Write the name of the following country*:<n>*USA*<n>*Write the name:<n>*Brazil*<n>*Write the following country:*<n>*Germany*<n>*Write:<n>*Australia*<n>*Write the state/province:*<n>*Idaho*<n>*Write the capital:*<n>*Boise*<n>*Write the city:*<n>*Sugar Land*<n>*Write the number:*<n>*6*<n>*Write the sentence:*<n>*Sarah is 4*<n><n># Summary<n>*The first letter of the first question will not be the first letter of the questions.<n>*If an option is not an acronym, you will be asked to use it.<n><n>

Even in a full immersive environment you make mistakes and misinterpretations occur more often. That can be uncomfortable. And that can cause frustration and misunderstandings.<n><n>### Response 2:<n>Learning a language was a painful and tedious experience for me. I remember a moment where my mind was wandering while my tutor kept asking me about my day. I couldn't answer and my mind kept thinking of all the things I could be doing back home. I wasn't even paying attention and my tutor's face told me it was time to switch into focus mode.<n><n>### Input<n>The boy tried to pick the mushroom, but it was too hard for him. Finally, he was able to pick the biggest mushroom in the group. He was really proud.<n><n>### Expected answer:<n>He failed.<n><n>### Answer:<n>I know why the boy failed.<n><n>## Input<n>The boy knew that his father was watching T.V in the living room. He went upstairs to his bedroom immediately. He heard thuds in the living room and he ran downstairs. He went into the living room and found a big hole in their wall, which made the thuds. Then he saw that dad was watching T.V on the floor because of the hole.<n><n>The expected answer should reflect the above input.<n><n>## Answer<n>The boy failed because he left his mother alone in the living room and went upstairs. He also ran upstairs and heard banging and noises in the living room. Instead of being more careful with the holes in the sheetrock, he was surprised to see dad watching T.V on floor, near the hole in the wall.<n><n><n>## Input:<n>When a fire alarm goes off in a school, your first reaction is to call the secretary's office to make sure the building is evacuated. Then you ask the students in your homeroom to account for themselves and to stay in the right place until the all clear is given. All of this may sound excessive, but you've been through a drill before and there's a reason for it.<n><n>## Expected answer:<n>If the fire alarm goes off, a teacher like me would have to make sure everyone in the class is ok.

Choices:  A: reach tentative agreement B: suicide C: examine thing D: commit murder E: stay in bed<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input<n>You want to find the minimum and maximum numbers for a specific variable.<n><n>### Output<n>You want the minimum and maximum values of the number for the input variable.<n><n>## #if/###elif ## Endif<n>If/elif constructs are commonly used constructs in languages like Python. They take a variable or expression as an input and determine whether or not it is less than or equal to a certain value. If the input is equal to (or less than) the specified value, the next elif test is performed. If all els have been evaluated, elif will continue with the if else blocks.<n><n>You can only have one #elif in an #if block.<n><n>### Input <n>You must determine which student failed the exam and why.<n><n>### Response<n>The two students that failed the exam are Jane and David.<n><n>### Constraints<n>There are no students named Jane or David, so you must be either one of these two students, or a different student.<n><n>### Processing<n>Find out which one of you failed and why you failed.<n><n>### Example<n>```<n>#if (exam_score == 10 && #if (#elif (#elif (student_type == "Jane") || (student_type ==<n>"David")))<n>#else<n>#endif<n>#endif<n>```<n><n>### Output :## #elif #else ### Endif<n>A #else block can help you avoid repeating code in multiple if/elif blocks. #else will only work with #if/elif statements, not with #if blocks.<n><n>### Except<n>### input <n>You are the headmaster of a school in England. A group of students have been making trouble in your school, disrupting classes, and breaking the rules. As a last resort, you decide to expel the entire class.<n><n>### response<n>The students had to leave the school even if they had good grades.<n><n>### constraint<n>The students left, but none of them had good grades when they left.<n><n>### process <n>You need to expel the entire group of students, even if they have many good grades.<n>### example<n>```<n>#if<n><n>### els ## if<n>An #if/elif process uses a loop to evaluate multiple expressions. The process is as follows

We have $50,084 in revenue, and $30,084 of expenses.  This leaves us with $20,000 profit.  (Because of rounding, it won't be exact.)  With 12 students and an estimated 40% profit, we should have an average profit of $500 per student, per dance.<n><n>### Example:<n>There are 5 students in a class. Choices:  A: hostility B: anger C: nose D: fists E: hands<n><n>### Response:		A: hostility<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>* John was punching at the solid wall. This was the act of a desperate man. He punched and punched the wall but succeeded only bloodying his knucle. There is no doubt that he tried hard to get the work done but ended up only with bleeding knucles without his desired resut. This act caused him to be in a bad situation. I'll have to say that this was the poor work done by John.<n><n>* He wasn't able to get the work done effectively because of his bad act. He was punching at a solid wall. He couldn't do it and he was only bloodying his fist without his desire resut. This was the worst act he did. We don't know anything about his angry act or about his hostility act. This was not the act John did. I have to pick hostility.<n>

The options presented here are outdated; however the choice is B. Since the refrigerator was not presented as an option, the choice here would be A as it is the best place in the store to put the food. Both options are correct.<n><n>### Input : Which one of these canned foods expires in about one year? Choices: 1: corn 2: pinto beans 3: pineapple juice 4: sardines 5: cocoa powder 6: peanut butter 7: pineapple<n><n>### Response : The correct response is 7- pineapple. All of the other foods expire but 2- pinto beans expires in about 5-6 years. 8- mushrooms are not mentioned. It is stated above the foods for the cans expire in about 1 year, so 6- peanut butter would expire in 5 months and 3- pinto beans in about six years. Pineapple is the correct answer.<n><n>### Answer 2<n><n>### Input  : In order to get a job in a warehouse, Jack needs to pass a math test. Jack is trying to figure out a way to make sure he passes. How long did Jack spend on the day of the test?<n><n>### Answer : 19 days<n><n>### Input / Analysis:<n><n>The first thing Jack tried to do was try these on his own but it did not work. Since he was not able to get past the math questions on his own, he then took a day for each question. There were 9 questions that took him a full day to complete. That would give him 9 times one day to answer 9 questions which would be

If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:Where do you buy tickets at a ticket booth for games/ Choices:  A: train station B: cathedral C: metro station D: fairgrounds E: amusement park<n><n>### Response:		<n>You would buy tickets at the metro station<n><n>### Input : Where do you get tickets at a station at sporting events<n><n>Choice: A: movie theatre B: school entrance C: airport D: stadium<n><n>### Your response:<n> You would get the tickets from the stadium<n><n>## Input:<n>Where would you get tickets to buy from at a cinema?<n><n>Choice: A : The train station B: Airports C: Fairgrounds D:Theatre<n><n>### My answer:<n>You would buy the tickets at the theatre  <n><n>## input:<n>Sylvia has a list of 24 canned foods. 12 of the foods have nutrition labels that show how many servings each can contains. 22 of the 24 foods in her kitchen are in cans.  If 3 cans of food have 2 servings each, which food has the most servings?<n><n>### Your answer:<n>The largest number of servings is 42 which is 18 servings of food and 24 cans of food<n><n>### Input<n><n>You earn $4 for every 15 oranges you sell.  You get $1 for every 8 apples you sell.  How much money you make from 46 lemons?<n><n>### My response<n><n> You get 1680 dollars<n>

She can travel for 40 miles in one hour each day. The boat can go six times faster than a speedboat that uses the same amount of fuel. She has decided that they should take the ferry home in two days of travel for her, but her younger sister thinks that it is possible to go home in one day of travel, how far can each person go, in miles, if they use the ferry to get home?<n><n>### Response<n>Sue is not able to go 200 miles without refueling because there are more than 140 miles between refueling stations. Her sister is only allowed to drive for four hours before making a stop at refueling stations. The older sister is able to make a longer trip because she makes more stops for fuel during shorter travel segments, but the younger sister does not have that option. The younger sister’s trip can only cover 140 miles and be completed in six hours of driving.<n><n>### InputA train and a car race down the same track between cities. On the first day, the car can go 70 miles farther than the train. Both are traveling in the same direction, but the train needs to make three stops to the car’s two. How many miles are each one when they reach their destination for the first day?<n><n>### responseThe train, when compared to the car, can make three stops. This helps it to travel 210 miles while the car can only travel 140 miles when compared to the train in terms of miles. The response is: The train's miles are 210, and the car's are 140.<n><n>### ResponseA: True<n>A: False<n><n>1: True<n>2: False<n><n>3: True<n><n>#### Answer: <n><n>### InputThe train left the city of Vancouver at 6:00 a.m. on Monday, which was a week later than the car. Input: Input: For every 10 cans you recycle you receive $0.10 and for every 2 kilograms of newspap ers, you receive $13.50; if your family recycled 1,345 cans and 28 kilograms of newspa per, how much money did you receive?<n><n>### Democracy<n><n>**Input:**The people of a small town are arguing over whether to use a plural form or a singular form when referring to the city. The group of the 10 citizens, with the most knowledge related to the rule of grammar for this particular case, are asked to take part in a vote. They are evenly divided among the sides of the argument. Choices:  A: bike B: downtown C: building D: tool storage E: car<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Write a recursive function that prompts the user for the sum of up to nine integers.  The program should print a message if a number is bigger than nine.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: Write a list of numbers to calculate the sum.<n><n>Response: Create a function that takes an integer variable to hold the sum and calls a function recursively until the sum is 10 or greater than 9.<n><n>### Function:sum(start) – Adds start to sum.<n><n>### Output<n><n>Output: If the sum is 11 (a sum of 11) the message should be "Congratulations!", otherwise, the message should be "Better luck next time."<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Function<n><n>```js<n>function sum(current) {<n>    if( current > 9 ) {<n>        sumEnding();<n>    } else {<n>        var newSum = current + 1;<n>        sum(newSum);<n>    }<n>}<n>function sumEnding() {<n>    var message = "Congratulations, your sum is " + sum;<n>    document.write("<p>" + message);<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Run<n><n>```js<n> sum(__(3,4,5,6,7,8,9,10));<n>```<n>

Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:What is the worst outcome of an injury? Choices:  A: cause death B: cause bleeding C: falling down D: become infected E: claim insurance<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input<n>If someone is injured at work, they can claim workers' compensation benefits.<n><n>### Input :Who collects the tax? They got as many tickets they wanted until every child matched up with every parent.<n>What was the probability that a child got paired with a parent who picked the same color as his own ticket?<n><n>    Input: <n>    (1) 4 red, 1 purple, and 11 green<n>    (2) The child's ticket<n>    (3) The parent's selected color<n><n>### Response:(Second Task)<n>Input:<n>B: (one of the red colors)<n>Output: 1/14<n><n>Input:(Second Task) Input: A: (one of the green colors)<n>Output:1/22<n>Input:(Second Task): Input: C: (one of the purple colors)<n>Output:0/22<n>Input(Second Task): Input: D: (one of the 13 black or grey colors<n>Output: 0/22<n><n>### Input :<n>Felix drives an ancient car with a rusted frame. Choices: <n>  A: go to the fire B: get out the hose C: ring the fire alarm D: shout at the dog that chases them to make her go home. E: run back to your house and hide.<n><n>Answer: D<n><n>I'll give you the answer then show you what my code looks like.<n><n>If there is only one line to write, the answer is the same as the input.<n><n>For multi lines, use the lines variable to create the answer string.<n><n><n>### Exact answer<n>  > A: walk B: run home and hide C: walk back <n><n>### Code:<n><n>```javascript<n>function answer(input) {<n>    console.log(lines[input])<n>}<n>answer("")<n>```<n>### Solution:<n>```<n>What would children do if<n>they are bored?<n><n>A: walk<n>B: change the shoes<n>C: play tag<n>D: smell smoke<n>E: reach over<n><n>A: walk back<n>B: change shoes<n>C: walk back<n><n>What would the children do,<n>if they walk, and see a fire?<n><n>A: get out the hoses<n>B: call the fire department<n>C: turn to the fire<n>D: shout on the dog that chases itself<n>E: run back to the house and go into hiding<n><n>A: get home and hose<n>B: call the Fire Department<n>C: walk back <n>```<n>### Example:<n>https://jsfiddle.net/1rLq7gvg/<n><n>### Run on your own:<n>```javascript<n><n>function answer(input){<n>    let answer<n><n>    switch (input) {<n><n>        case'':<n>            answer = lines[11]<n>            break;<n><n>        }<n><n>    console.log('Answer is '+ answer)<n>}<n><n>answer('')<n>```<n><n>*https://jsfiddle.net<n><n>> https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/First_steps/Decision_making<n>

If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:In what place could you find air that has been breathed by only a few people recently? Choices:  A: train station B: house C: cupboard D: cricket stadium E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are many places air can be found that has been breathed only by a few people recently. An easy to breathe example of a place that has been breathed in by many people recently is the public bathroom because it is often open to most people. Another way to figure out if a place is recently breathed by very few people is to look at the calendar on a wall or in the newspaper. There are more than just a few places where air has been breathed by many people recently. A train station would be a good example of a place that was not too long ago breathed by only a very few people because you can often see a lot of people walking through train stations frequently. If there are a lot of people in a house then it is likely that air in that room has recently been breathed by many more people than in a cupboard because it is used by the people in that house all the time. Even though cricket stadiums aren’t used all the time by many people, because cricket is a widely popular game, the air in that stadium has most likely breathed by a lot of people who attended a cricket game or used the stadium in the past. Likewise, Earth is the perfect place to breathe because people all over the world breathe.<n><n>### Input:(7 + 35 + 19 × 1) / 12 =<n>### Response:The answer to this problem is 18. This problem is best explained with variables. Let ____ stand for “(7 + 35... + 19 ×...);” and ____ stand for “/ 12 =.” First, we will set ____ equal to something, like 25 and then let _____ stand for the answer to the same problem (with ____ equal to 26). So, ____ =25. The question asks to plug in the variable ____ into _____. Because ____ = 25, we add in 25, which is 50. We then take away 50 from the first part of the equation which would leave the number 0. Then we take away the fraction 12 from the second part of the equation which leaves the number 3, which is the answer. We can simplify this equation by using “/” as one variable and using it as either the divisor or the dividend. This is because we do

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. Afterwards, decide which of the choices, corresponds to the numbered box. You will write the word, "corresponding" in the box.<n><n>Here is an example of a completed task.<n>Input: What is (D) ( B ) corresponds (C) ( a ) of 23.4 * 0.8?<n><n>Solution:<n><p>&nbsp;(a) 0.8 corresponds 23.4</p><n><n><p>&nbsp;&nbsp;(B) corresponds (D) (<span style="color:red">1&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;5-4.4=0.6&amp;nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span>8</p><n>

How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:The other passengers on the bus were quite loud, so he put on his headphones to relax and what? Choices:  A: go to bed B: sleep C: listen to music D: stretch out E: stop worrying<n><n>### Response:		<n>A.B.C.D.E.<n><n>#### Explanation<n><n>You should use the same method of thinking as before. But this can get to your head.<n><n>You have two possibilities for the correct answer (A,B,C,D,E). You have to answer the right one.<n><n>As the passenger is listening to relaxing music, the answer must be in his favor.<n><n>Also, there are too many people talking on the bus. <n><n>So he wants to listen to music and he can do this, and he listens to music.<n><n>A) The other passengers on the bus are quite loud – put on his headphone to relax =  (Answer)<n><n>B) The other passengers on a bus were quite loud – put on headphones to relax = Different Thinking<n><n>C) The bus full of other passengers was quite loud – put on the headphones to relax. = Different Thinking with Different Answer<n><n>D) The other passengers on one bus are quite loud – he put on headphones just to relax. = D) He is not interested in other passengers.<n><n>E) He put on his headphona just to relax – as the other passengers on the bus is full of noise. = E) He listened to only one passengers<n><n>Hope, you understand.<n><n>**Author:** [Hazel Oliveira](https://github.com/hazel-oliveira)<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: movie B: cape kennedy C: space center D: military installation E: spaceship centre<n><n>### Response:		None of these<n><n>### Input, Demonstration:You are playing a 4-player game. To start, 11 dominoes are placed face up  in a row. For each round, you may place a domino in a hole at the left end of the line, or you may place the domino from that hole in front of you, to form your new line. If a hole that you placed the domino in had a domino in it to begin with, then you cannot make a choice to place  that domino’s piece. For example, if a particular hole contains 5 dominoes, then you cannot place the corresponding piece in that hole. You have no choice but to take the domino from that particular hole and place it in front of you. But there is a  limitation: you may only take a domino from the hole if you  are the only person who has put 1 of that domino’s pieces in that hole during the course of the game. Choose the option that will start you on the path to victory.  A: Take the pieces that were placed face up in the first round and place them in a single pile in front  of you, forming a new line. B: Place the pieces that were only ever placed on top of existing pieces in a single  pile in front of you, forming a single pile. C: Place the pieces in front of you and choose the 1st domino with 1 remaining piece in  it (if 2 are left, choose the one on the left). D: Repeat your choice from the previous round. E: Place the pieces in your hand face down. F: Place the pieces in a single pile that are those that were not already  placed face up in previous rounds. G: Place the pieces in the hand of the person who is currently winning. H: Leave the pieces unchanged.<n><n>### Input - Demonstration:It started on a quiet night as a bright sunset came, everyone in the room was fast asleep..until one started counting sheep. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:He wore the wrong shoes while walking all day, now he has what on his heels and toes? Choices:  A: exercise B: moving forward C: feet D: blisters E: locomotion<n><n>### Response:		In the case of footwear, the more walking you do, the more it increases your chance of a blister or some such thing.

The grade for the cumulative average is determined by adding the letter grades for all three assignments and taking the average. If a student has received 3 A’s, the cumulative average is A+, and he or she will receive all A’s for the next year. If a student has not received all A’s for 3 assignments, then the letter grade for that student’s cumulative average drops to A−. How many grades were received from the three assignments?<n><n>Example: Input: The student received one A, one A- and one B for the three assignments.<n><n>Answer: <n><n>Output: <n>6<n><n>Input: The students went on a field trip to the aquarium. To do this, they needed to bring three lunches for the day. Each lunch they made cost $1 per lunch. On the last day of school, Mr. Brown wanted to take the students to a pizza place for lunch. The pizza place only serves medium pizza. The student can order a regular, small or medium pizza at the pizza place. Which pizzas cost the most? Choices: A: Small one B: Regular sized one C: Medium one D: Don't know because there is no pizza place nearby<n><n>Answer: Small sized<n><n>### Input<n>The students went on a field tri…<n><n>### Instructio…<n><n>### Response<n>Input: If you eat eight servings of vegetables in a week, you get 75% off a yearly produce subscription. How many servings of vegetables should you eat in a week if you want to get a yearly produce subscription for free?<n>Answer: 37<n><n>Input: A student has $75 in a savings account

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:What would you do if you have curiosity about something but cannot leave your house? Square is a structure with two floating-point values and two floating-point values for the perimeter and area. The "square" class uses constructor syntax as well as copy-constructors. Please see class Square.cpp, constructor statements and the copy-constructors.<n>```<n><n>```<n>### Input:<n>Write a test case and describe the modification at the program level, and the data level in a program.<n>### Request: Describe the modification, and how the program data will be affected.<n>### Response: <n><n>### Input :<n><n>```<n>public class Area implements Comparable<Area> {<n>  protected double side1, side2;<n>  protected double perimeter, area;<n><n>  public Area(double side1, double side2) {<n>    this.side1 = side1;<n>    this.side2 = side2;<n>    this.perimeter = 2 * side1 + 2 * side2;<n>    area = perimeter / 2;<n>  }<n><n>  public Area copy() {<n>    return new Area(side1, side2);<n>  }<n><n><n>  @Override<n>  public int compareTo(Area a) {<n>    return Double.compare(a.getArea(), this.getArea());<n>  }<n><n>}<n>```<n><n><n><n><n>In the class Square, we want to return the area of a rectagular object that is less than or equal to it's side lengths (that is, we know that the area cannot be greater than the sides; the user will know if they are trying to enter areas that are greater than the sides, for the square case, so they will know right away). So we could return 0 in that case, to indicate a failure when trying to divide by 0; or we could return a negative, again, like 0, so that the user knows they are out of bounds and not to continue with their calculation. In this way, the test case we create would have the following

Then the code takes the 2 numbers and multiplies them, and then divides the answer by 40. For example, if you put in the numbers 12 and $.50 into recycleAmount, then recycleAmount would return 9.33333 because

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:He was looking for the holiday decorations and found an old box of clothes up where? Choices:  A: attic B: trash C: loft D: closet E: box<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>

Choices:  A: confusion B: complications C: riot D: arrest E: protests<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>  D<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### Instructions:Write a response for each choice. Choices are given in parenthesis.<n><n>### Demo response:<n><n>Instruction: A:  C:  D:<n><n>### Input (Say It Like This):<n><n>What kind of action should you start because of the following problems: (Your response should be the same for both questions)<n><n>  * (D) <n><n>  * (A)<n><n>  *...<n><n>### Demo Response (Say It Like That):<n><n>Write the response that answers the following questions:<n><n>Q. Write a response that answers the following: (Your response should answer both questions)<n><n>   What kind of action should you do because of the following problems...<n><n>Q. Your friend was injured while biking and broke his shoulder. Would you take him to: (Your response should name the doctor)<n><n>  * <n><n>  *  (The response should answer both questions.)<n><n>### Examples:<n><n>### Note:<n>The following items include some hints and clues. Follow the instructions to complete these questions.<n><n>  * A: In this problem, you must decide if you do any kind of civil action because someone did something wrong, for example, to set the matter right.<n>  * B: In this problem, they describe that someone is trying to solve the matter. But, your job is not to do anything about it.<n>  * C: This problem uses some of the clues from item A. Your job is to explain and give information.<n>  * D: This problem is about giving a response to something that is said.

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. For every 12 pairs of shoes, you receive $0,50.<n>II. For every 10 feet, you receive $0 dollar.<n>So,  for every 12 pairs you get $0,5 dollar, and for every 100 feet you get $0 dollar, that’s 10 * 10 = 100.<n><n>Input:You can count to 22 without saying any numbers. How many numbers would you need to say to count from 1 to 22?<n><n>Input: 3 ÷ 5 =?<n><n>You multiply or divide the one number by the other number from left or right.<n>It doesn’t matter if the division is 87 ÷ 3 or 3 ÷ 87.<n>However, when you have a fraction, the number before the fraction is called the numerator, and the number after it is called the denominator.<n>When the denominator is expressed as a power of Ten, it is called a scientific notation.<n><n>### First Example<n>3 / 5 == 0.6<n>You can't divide by zero, and then you can't divide either of those numbers by 0.<n>So, 0.6!= 1.0<n><n>### Second Example<n>41 / 5 = 8.2<n><n>41 / 8.2 = 5.0<n><n>## Input<n>What’s 7 times 2?<n><n>Input<n>Input: 400-34=?<n><n>400–34= 366<n><n>65% of 8 is 53.<n><n>## Input:<n>How is 350 / 15 the same as 7?<n><n>## Detailed Response<n>350 divided by 15 will give us 23, so we can say that x * y = 23.<n>Now we can solve:<n><n>(7 * 7 / 15) / 2 is what we get.<n><n>So from our

Choices:  A: get angry B: concern C: worrie D: education E: learning about world<n><n>### Response:		A=91<n><n>### Demont:What do you get when you subtract?<n><n>### Response:: Answer: D<n><n>### Instructions:  How high above sea level is the summit of Mauna Kea?<n><n>### Demination:Write the name of the mountain on a piece of paper and calculate the elevation in feet if the summit at the top is 69601 feet.<n><n>### Response A: 5816. 601 x 5816 = 343792<n><n>### Response B: 6960 - 5816 feet = 1144 feet<n><n>### Instrutions:  The average weight of an adult elephant is what?<n><n>### Input : Choices:  A : 5100 lbs B: 5200 lbs C: 4600 lbs D: 2800 lbs E: 958 <n><n>### Reponses:A=6600 lb B=3 lb<n><n>### Demotivation:  Write and execute a java program that calculate your IQ based on your age. Input is your age, and the output is your iq.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>```<n>public class Iq {<n>private int age;<n>public static double function(int age) {<n>  if (age<13) {<n>    return Math.floor(age/ 20.0) - 1;<n>  }<n>  if (age <= 18){<n>    return 86.4*age-22.8;<n>  }<n>    <n>  return 115.2-1.54;<n>}<n>public static void main(String args[]) {<n>	   int age=9;<n>  double iq=function(int age); <n>  System.out.println("Your iq is "+iq);<n>}<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Insturction : You need to store a string in memory. Write a program that will accept the user input and store it in memory. Give both the input and output using your own words. You don't need to type the instructions in the program.<n><n>### Solutions :<n><n>```<n>public
Below is an instruction that describes a task. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:I'm watching tv because there is nothing else to do, what do I expect to get from this? Choices:  A: erections B: entertainment C: boredom D: get fat E: sadness<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A. A.<n><n>### Justification:<n><n>A. Choice for A.<n><n>## Input:<n>I bought 10 tissues so I won't get sick and I want my sister to stop touching me.<n><n>## Response:<n><n>I would buy 5.<n><n>## Justification:<n><n>I buy 5 since you have to multiply by 4, 10 times 4 is 40 tissues.<n><n>### Input<n>What should you multiply by 4? Choices: B: C: D: E:  A. 1 B. 5 C. 10 D. 20 E. 40<n><n>### Response<n>A.<n><n>### Response justification:<n><n>It is 25 since B is the only one that adds up to 40.<n>

Choices:  option 1: A: go on a trip  B: buy a car C: stay home  D: build a swimming pool**<n><n>### Response<n>**Option 2**<n>Stay home<n><n>### Explication<n><n>The answer is to stay home. A trip, a car and a swimming pool are expensive items for home use. While you may still enjoy these items, you could have more fun staying home.<n><n>### The solution should indicate all the options, including <n><n>**Option 1**<n>Go on a trip<n><n>**Option 2 or 3**<n>Stay home <n><n>**Option4**<n>Buy a car<n><n>**Option5**<n>Build a swimming pool<n><n>### <n><n>### 1: You are writing to your cousin in China who asked you for information on a new law that gives all students time for homework. Choices:  A: bushes B: dessert C: books D: heat lamps E: rocks<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: E: Heat Lamps<n><n>### Why does this approach work?<n><n>### Link:<n>[Bash](/bash/input-and-output-python-program/)<n><n>### Your challenge:<n>Your challenge is to design an algorithm and write Python code to do the following tasks. In this program you will be inputting both strings and numbers into variables. **You will not be using for loops, while loops, or if statements in this program.** <n><n>### To use:<n>First, create a class by extending the __str__ method from the Python programming language. You need to get the user input and print it out. Your job will be to ask for an integer and then print both the integer and a message that says how much we multiplied by.<n><n>### Challenge:<n>Once you are finished building the class, you need to make sure your program prompts the user for a string. Your program will be responsible for taking both a string and an integer and calculating how much of the string a specific number of characters long the number of times. You will need to test your program and be able to write some meaningful print statements to test your work and make sure everything is working.<n><n>### Additional challenge<n>Write your own version of the __str__ method.<n><n>### Note:<n>The following methods will be used in this exercise:__str__, integer, and string.<n><n>### HINT:<n>If you don't know how to extend __str__ and the other methods, you can visit [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/python).<n><n>### Solution:<n>```python<n>class MyObject:<n><n>    def __init__(self, my_string: str):<n>        self.__objString = my_string<n><n>    def __str__(self) -> str:<n>        return self.__objString<n><n>    def multiplication(self) -> str,float:<n>        multiple = input("type in the number of times the object should be multiplied: ")<n>        <n>        if multiple <= 1:<n>            return ""<n>        <n>        if not multiple < 1:<n>            print("wrong input")<n>            <n>        object = MyObject(multiple)<n>        <n>        print(object)<n>        print(str(object))<n>        multiply = int(object)<n>        <n>        multiple_

Choices:  A: hiding B: accidentally C: expectation D: knowingly E: planned<n><n>### Response:		100<n>

Choices:  A: fresh water B: gulf of mexico C: open ocean D: television program E: coral reef<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input<n>If the shark had been migrating and biologists found it somewhere, then it would still be migrating somewhere.<n>### Response<n>Different species have different habitats. What is the probability that at least one sales executive will gain exactly 17 new insight?<n>### Response: 0.9558<n><n>### Input Each question had 5 options, out of which only 3 were correct, leaving 2 incorrect options. What is the conditional probability that question 5 was correct if questions 1 to 4 were all incorrect?<n>### Response 0.2308<n><n>### Instructions: The question asks you to find the probability that the answer is True.<n>### Input: You will roll a standard fair die until you roll a 5. What is the conditional probbality that the color of your first roll will be red?<n><n>### Responses. For each correct answer, provide an explanatation<n>- 1st correct: If you roll a 6 on your first roll then any following rolls will not be red, so what you're asking for is finding out what the probability of the first roll to be red is. The probability is 1/6 since once the die is in motion, that's the chance that the next roll will be red.<n><n>- 2nd correct: The probability that the first roll is red will be 5/6 if you roll a 6 in your first roll.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:What do customers do in a store? Choices:  A: hunt B: pay merchants with money C: mail orders D: spend money E: demand satisfaction<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A<n>### Answer Key:<n><n>B <p>B</p><n><n>C <p>B</h4><n><n>D <p>A</p>

Choices:  A: airplane B: ship's hold C: boat D: truck E: train<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Cargo<n>Input: What is a fast but expensive method of sending cargo? <n>If Cargo costs more then airplane then:<n>if Cargo costs more then boat then:<n>if Cargi costs more then ship's hold then:<n>if Cargin costs more then truck then:<n>else: Cargin<n><n>### Input<n>Your uncle sells cars. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:What is a useful activity when experiencing loneliness? Choices:  A: meet people B: meet friend C: make people laugh D: socialize E: liquor<n><n>### Response:		The best answer is A<n><n>### Why:<n>- This problem has multiple different answers. <n>- If the person is in a dark room and only has one candle, option B would not be helpful as she would also want some friends to help her get out of the room.<n>- Option C - making people laugh - it means this person is shy.<n>- Option D - socialize - if she already has a lot of friends, she should socialize more, and this is not useful.<n>- The best answer is A, which is to find new friends.<n>- This is a situation where she wants to find new friends.

Subtracting one from the smaller, 24 is obtained and subtracting the larger, 230 is got. Add this to the smaller and 2 is obtained. Increase the larger and 8 is obtained. This is the 4252nd letter of the alphabet.<n><n>### Response H<n><n>### input<n> 1. 5 people are competing to win a $600 prize by being the first to solve a maze. The crowd consists of 40 people and each has a different, unique reaction when asked to give a clue.<n>  1. For every 12 cabs you recycle, you earn $ 50, and for each 25 bottles of aluminum bottles, you earn $1.50; How much money would you earn by recycling 92 cabs and 36 bottles of aluminium?<n><n>You can do:<n>1) $12 $50 =1250$36 $1.50 = 54$1. $50 + $54 =$ 104$36 $104 =$ 358$51 + $60 =$ 111$60 $358 =$ 418$111 + $90 =$ 201$90 +$30= $120<n>(add $50 to $120 =$170)<n><n>2) $12 $1.50 +$36 $60 $66 $40 $460<n><n>To write a program to create a solution, you can create an array of strings using an array of strings for input and a string to store your program's answer. Teacher borrow 3, return 7. <n>   <n>  N = (Input - 9)  = (Input - 100)/10  = 1(1-0)  = 1 + (-100)  = 999<n><n> 2. Teacher borrow 1, return 4<n>   <n>  N1 = (Input - 5) = (Input - 81)/8   = (Input - 4)/8 = (Input - 23)/8 = 4(23)/8 =357<n><n><n>### Input1 : Alice borrow 100, Bob borrow 0. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:Where would you read a passage but not write it? Choices:  A: diary B: city C: bible D: graffiti E: labyrinth<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>- The bible?<n><n><n>

Please explain your work. Hint: The same rule can be used for every child.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>John’s two sons will get the same amount.<n><n>### Answer: Rule #1: Div 2 1 11 divide rule #2: 1 + 1 1 0 2<n><n>### Input How many days after Monday, if Monday is May 28, is the day before Friday?<n><n>### Solution:<n>> 20<n><n>### Description:<n>> The question is asking for the day's name before Friday. Wednesday is one day before Friday.<n><n>### Input A new house is constructed on a piece of land. The house is made up of two rooms, each 50 meters away from each other. He likes to fish for perch and catches 40 perch in one afternoon. For a long time he has been curious about how many pennies there are in 40 perch. He knows that he gets 0.10 perch if he sells his fish. Do you know how many pennies John catches?<n><n>### Demostration: 180<n><n>### Rationale Explaination<n><n>For each fish John sells, there are 5 dollars. So, 0.10 dollars will go with 5 dollars. So John will get 5 dollars and $0.10. Thus, there are 21 10 dollar notes in 40 fish.<n><n>### Choose the letter that indicates whether the student's response below is A for acceptable, or B for below the standard for this exercise.<n><n>### I agree with the solution of this problem<n><n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demstation<n>16<n><n>### Input : How much bread was there in the loaf of bread that is left over from the school picnic?<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Destionation<n>4<n><n>### Instuctions<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Rationalization<n>If Tom buys 2 loaves of bread each costing $2.40 and Tom sells them for $4 each, then he makes a profit of 6 dollars.<n><n>### Destiation<n>5<n><n>### Insturctions: Answer the following short answer question<n><n>### Desteination<n>7<n><n>### Input  : Tom has two cows. Choices:  A: shoes B: wet ground C: wet clothes D: start to fall E: water garden<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>---<n>### Output:<n>The program is successful.<n><n>---<n><n>### Example:<n>The above example is used to test your response. Your program should not prompt for any input. If you are asked to enter any data, enter the data from above (12, 40, 160, 245, 14, 130). The program should generate the following message.  If your program generates any other message, your program is incorrect.  If there are any other issues, your program is incorrect too.  You can submit the program in different sessions, but in each session, you should get the same message.<n><n>Input: Why shouldn't you walk in a garden after it rains?<n><n>Choice: B<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>The above program is incorrect.<n><n>---<n>## The following are the steps for you to generate the responses.<n><n>### 1. Read the complete sentence as input for the program.<n><n>### Example sentence:<n>``You have an array of 500 ints, and you want to print them on two lines, separated by a comma. The first line of the output must not contain any spaces before or after the comma. The format of the array is: {534,298,45}``.<n><n>### Test:<n>Print the array on two lines, separated with a comma. The first of the lines must not contain any spaces on the left or right of the comma. The format for the array is: {int}<n><n>### Solution:<n>```<n>#include <stdio.h><n>#include <string.h><n>int printArray(int array[], int size, char input[50], char output[50]){<n>	int a,i;<n>	sprintf(output,"\n"+input);<n>	for (a=0; a<size; a++)	{<n>		sprintf(output+strlen(output), "%d", array[a]);<n>		for (i=0; i<3; i++) {<n>			if (array[a] < 100)<n>				output[strlen(output)] = '0' + array[a];<n>			else<n>				break;<n>		}<n>		sprintf

Since the cost of the car does not rise as much as the amount you spend on gas. This is true with years as the car gets older.*

As car engines need to absorb shocks to run smoothly, they must contain metals that are flexible and strong, such as [iron carbide]. In modern engines, [aluminum] is also used for better weight distribution. The [steering] contains [metal rods] as the steering wheel communicates with the car's brakes and wheels via wires and metal connectors to regulate how the wheels turn in relation to the direction of steering.<n><n>Choice B (answer):<n><n>Metal bars can be found in airplanes, where they often form [bars]. The [exhaust pipe] can be made by [steel mesh]. Steel tubes are used to make [stabilizers]. [Metal bars make up the wing struts] of an airplane. [Metal bars] can also be found in the [body of the car].<n><n>Choice C (answer):<n><n>Steel is found in road signs. In modern shops, [metal rods are found in a lot of places]. For example, [metal rope chains are used in a shop's cash registers]. [Wooden] or [metal rods that hold up the shelves] of a shop are also commonly used. The shelves of a shop commonly have [metal bars]. If the shop is large enough and old enough, [metal bars] might be [rusted with age].<n><n>Choice D (answer):<n><n>The [exhaust pipe]. [The valve stem]. [Metal rods that connect to its engine system]. The [valve rod]. [The engine rod], where they are [most likely] to break.<n><n>Choice E (answer):<n><n>When someone has a [broken bone], the common treatment for that person is for a [surgical] [rod] to be installed in the bone to help [heal].<n><n>### Input<n>How much does 8 ounces of corn weigh?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Choice A (response):<n><n>[8 ounces of](answer): [This is about 240 grams][of corn].<n><n>> **Explanation**: [8 oun

How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:Ben was an alcoholic and was in an accident.  Because of his mistake, he spent 8 years somewhere. Where was he? He then picked a handful of 18 marbles and placed those in the jar. Which of the following is the actual number of marbles in the jar?<n><n>### Response<n>50<n><n>### Description<n>Jeremiah was given 2 options; the correct 1 being the one that would leave us with the least amount of marbles. Jeremiah placed 12 and then 18 marbles, and at the end he told us that there were less than 50. So, from here we can conclude that there were 30 marbles left. Then if we take 12 from that, there will be 18 marbles left, which is more than 50, so it's actually not 50.<n>

Use the ternary operator to return a string that reflects the if-else statement's output.<n>Input: In case you have to make hard decisions sometimes, you'll have to prepare yourself to take on tough consequences. You can avoid toughest parts by making a ternary function.<n>Response: Your function should take in a boolean input, then return a string.<n><n>### Input<n>```js<n>var ageTernary = createTernaryFunction("are you 20 or older");<n>```<n><n>### Demos<n>Input: The function checks if the age is below 20 years. It checks if the condition is true. If the condition is true, it returns the string "YES" otherwise "NO". You can now pass 40 as the age and check that it prints YES.<n>```js<n>ageTernary(40)<n>```<n><n>Output: NO.<n><n>Input: The function in-case if takes 2 args(the age and the <n>condition) and it returns the string as the output. You can check the condition using a check function. In this case it checks if the age is lesser than 50 and if so, it returns "YES" as output.<n>```js<n>if (ageTernary(50) == "YES"){<n>  console.log("YOU MUST BE 50 YEARS OLD");<n>}<n>```<n><n>Output:"YOU MUST BE<n>50 YEARS<n>OLD".<n><n>Input: Ternary operator takes 3 input, it takes condition and if it is true it returns 2 input of the function, i and j, else when condition is false it checks the if-else statement of i and j and returns whatever the function returns. <n>You should write the function now.<n><n>### Response<n><n>```js<n>function createTernaryFunction(isCool){<n>  if (isCool){<n>    return "are you below 20 years or older?";<n>  }else{<n>    return areYouBelow20YearsOld();<n>  }   <n>}<n>```<n>### Instrucrions:Write a function that takes an array as

If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:When would you be able to see your reflection in a piece of wood? How many 8-second verses will the song have? Choices: A: four B: three C: two D: one E: none]<n><n>### Response:[This is easy. The song can only have a maximum of four verses, because 8 second times 4 is 32 seconds.<n><n>###Input:I have 3 liters and 4 liters, with 8 more liters than the volume of the first container. The volumes of the two containers differ by the same factor. How many liters are in each container?<n><n>###Response:[There are several ways of answering this. A very simple way is to do volume in the first container to the power 3 and then subtract volume in the second container to the power 4. This will give you the answer 35 which is what you need.<n><n>###Output: You are given an equation that contains variables and letters of the alphabet. Choices:<n>A: a big city.<n>B: a small town.<n>C: shopping mall.<n>D: in a rural location.<n>E: in a new town.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Response: D<n><n>#### [Explanation for the choice 'D']<n>Store in small town.<n><n><n>### Task<n><n>Task: If I want to maximize the number of salesmen we can hire, where should we build our factories to hire them from? Choices:<n><n>A: New York City<n>B: Outer Mongolia<n>C: rural farms of Canada<n>D: Outside USA<n><n>### Response1<n><n>Response: D New York City<n><n>#### [Exhibit for the choice 'D', New York City]<n><n>If we build the factory in New York City, we can employ more salesmen<n><n><n>### Response2<n><n>Response: A<n><n>#### [Existence for the choice 'A', New York City] New York city is a big city<n><n>If we build our factory in new York city, we can employ more people<n><n><n>### Conclusion<n><n>The factory located in New York city<n><n><n>### Analysis<n><n>The goal of the question is to make a comparison between 2 choices<n><n>New York city > Shopping Mall > A Town<n><n><n>### Explanation 1<n>**Response1**

Choices:  A: art room B: police station C: classroom D: desk drawer E: school<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>If you recycle 12 cans, you receive 0.50$. If you recycle 1 can, you receive 0$. If you recycled 12 million cans, would you get 12$ or 0$?<n>```<n>If you collect 144 can and 20 kilogram of newspapers, you collect 2740 kg. It cost 1$ for every 1 kg of newspapers you collected. Therefore, you would receive 12$ (2740 kg * 1.50$).<n><n>```<n>What building has a ot glue bottles?<n>A : Art room -> The art room has lots of glue bottles. K is an artist, she will need to fix the painting she drawes.<n>B : Police station -> Police station doesn't have any glue bottles<n>C : Classroom -> Most of the classrooms have a lot of glue bottles<n>D : Desk drawer -> Most of the teachers keep some glue bottles of the desk drawers.<n>E : School -> Almost all buildings will have glue bottles<n><n>```<n><n>### Input 2<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration:Betty picked 16 stwrawberies. This means that the average of the ages of all the people playing the game equals 48. Choices: True; False<n><n>###Response B: An average sale price of a car is $13000. This means that the cost of all cars sold in the United States is $130,000,000. Choices: True ; False<n><n><n>### Response C: The average amount of money a family pays for food every month will be $2.50x(A) + $1.00x(B)+0x(C). this means that you will multiply the number of days in a months into A and B, then add to the total. If you buy food for 30 days a month and the values of A and B were $2.00 and $1.00, respectively.<n><n><n>##Instruction: The expression 4A - 3B represents the number of days from January 1 to Valentine

Choices:  A: stress B: debate C: argument D: winning or losing E: tension<n><n>### Response:		You might get into stress or tension. This is an emotion that both people experience during the competition, which is usually mental.<n><n>### Inputs:Jack runs a marathon in 3 hours, while Alice runs a marathon in just over 2 hours. Based on their races, what else would we be able to infer about them? Choices: A: both are slow B: both are fast C: their marathons have similar lengths D: their marathons are very different.<n><n>### ResponseTheir marathon lengths are very different. We know that both Jack and Alice run a marathon without knowing other information other than the marathon lengths. This information that includes their running speed or if they use similar strategies for their marathon. Hence, we can infer that their marathon lengths are very diverse as one is 3 hours compared to another’s 2 hours long.<n><n>### What else may we know about the person who answered the question above? Choices: A person is knowledgeable about other people. B: The person likes marathons. C: The person is from an athletic family. D: The person is always in a hurry. E: The person values quality time with others.<n><n>### RespondThe person answers questions that may not be related to the topic they provide to get other people to believe answers from the person without knowing what is asked, which means he is quite knowledgeable about other people’s answers to get other people to answer questions. Moreover, the person tends to be the person who asks unrelated questions, which means that the person is probably from an athletic family background.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>Input: James dumps his whole collection of 500 Legos on the floor and starts building a castle out of them.  He uses half the pieces before finishing and is told to put the rest away.  He puts all of the leftover pieces back in the box they came from, except for 5 missing pieces that he can't find.  How many Legos are in the box at the end?<n>Answer: 245<n><n>Input: Ines had $20 in her purse. She bought 3 pounds of peaches, which are $2 per pound at the local farmers’ market. How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10. If he pays $80 in the first year, how much does his membership cost, in dollars, in the sixth year?<n>Answer: 130<n><n>### Input:Where is a paper notice likely to be left on a house? Choices:  A: front door B: conference C: classroom D: refrigerator E: suitcase<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input<n>In school, your teacher assigns each child 2 minutes to read after lunch, and all students are divided into groups based on how they performed on the reading comprehension test from the previous year. There are 6 children who read fast and 4 who read slower, except the teacher has 4 children from the slow group reading, while the fast group has 3 fewer children than the slow group. How many children are there?<n><n>### Response<n>In order to solve the question we need to work out: the number children in first group, the number children in second group and then the number children in total<n><n>We can get the numbers by using a simple formula: $number\_total(n_1 + n_2 + n_3 + n_4 + n_ 5)$<n><n>so:<n><n>$(7 + 6) + 6 = 6(13) + \frac{3}{2} =24$ $number\_total = 4(10)$<n><n>The four numbers in which each child can read fast and all of them make 20.<n><n>$\begin{aligned}\begin{array}{rcl} n_1 & = & 2 \\ n_2 & = & 2\\ n_3 & = & 4 \\ n_4 & = & 4\end{array}\end{aligned}$<n><n>$$4(10)=(20-1) - \frac{3}{4}$$ $number\_total = $ $1$<n><n><n><n>### Input : The classroom is filled with children’s blocks and chairs.  How many kids are there? Choices: 587, 61, 222, 112, 74, 135, 83, None of these.<n><n>### Response : 112<n><n>For this one we need to do some thinking. First, we need to find the total so we can take a look at how many children we have for each of the categories. The first child has 2 blocks. The second child has 1, the third has 3, and so on. The fourth through seventh have 4 blocks. The eighth through fourteen each have 1 block, while the fourteenth child has 2. Here are all of the ways that the 32

Choices:  A: tear up B: see light C: fill with tears D: be happy E: glass over<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**Correct**.<n>A<n><n>### Comments:<n><n>#### How I would do this:<n><n>I think it would help to start by identifying the key words. For each of the input questions, there is a word 'first', and so the thing that comes first is something that has never happened before. It could be the first time something has happened before, before it happens again. This might not always be the word 'first', however, so it might be better to say that a key question in each has is 'which has never happened before?'<n><n>For the rest of the questions, it's worth noting that each word in the question, has two words before and after it, so you can use this to help identify the key word.<n><n>For the first question, 15(2 + 6) + 3(3) + 2(2) = 12<n><n>The next question is a bit trickier! Betty picked 16. Matthew picked 21 and twice as many as Betty.<n>20x3 = 60<n><n>Jack has a stack of books 12 inches thick x 80 pages = 96O books<n><n>James has 500 Legs, out of the 501, he is missing 5. 500(1/2) = 250<n><n>Aaron has $80 in the year, and is always $10 more each year. 80x10 = 800<n><n>When a newborn' beds eyes open for the first times, it could be the first time it's ever been happy. Choices: A: tear up<n><n>The next is a little vague as the word 'open' refers to a range of things:  eyes opening, and beds being opened.<n><n><n>### Notes:<n>

Choices: 1 minute 5 minutes 12 minutes 6 hours<n><n>### Response:(Answer to the question in response)<n>Input: What is the smallest?<n><n>### Response<n>Output:0<n>### Instruction<n>#### How to test this code?<n>In Java we normally test code with the assertions or the assert keyword to make certain the condition is true.  Here you have used a number operator to make the if statement.  I would have used an assertion to see if the code was working.<n><n>```<n>for (i = 0; i < 10; i++)<n>{<n>    System.assert(i < 100);<n>    System.assert((10 - i) < 10);<n>    System;<n>    if (i >= 7 && i <= 10)<n>    {<n>        System.out.println("1. " + i);<n>    }<n>    if (i == 5)<n>    {<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n><n>Above are 3 examples on how to test these conditional statements in java.<n><n>### Solution<n>```<n>public static int main (String [] args){<n>    <n>    //testing the less than statements<n>    if(10 < 9)<n>    {<n>      System.out.println(“the if is true”);<n>    }<n>    <n>    // testing the equality statements<n>    if(5 == 5)<n>        System.out. print("the " + "5's are equal");<n>    <n>    <n>    // test the "greater than" operator<n>    if (1 < i)<n>        if (i < 10)<n>        {<n>            System.out.println (“one  is less  than  i”);<n>        }<n>        else {<n>            System.<n>            //testing the greater than, less than operator<n>            if(10 > 9)<n>            {<n>                System.out.println ("greater " + "than ");<n>                }<n>            //testing the less than equal operator<n>            else if(8 <= 8)<n>                    System.out.println (. " less than "<n>              = " = ");<n>            <n>            <n>            <n>

How much did she have left?<n>Answer: 14<n><n>Input: Aaron pays his actuary membership fees each year. The membership fee increases yearly by $10.
